Al/graphite battery with an IL electrolyte and its ion intercalation process upon charging. (b) CV curves (scan rate: 0.5 mV s−1; cutoff voltage: 2.45 V) of the Al/HOPG batteries with EMICl-AlCl3 (black) and HMICl-AlCl3 (red) electrolytes. The curves from 1.80 to 1.95 V are enlarged in the inset. (c) XPS N 1s signals for the EMICl-AlCl3 and HMICl-AlCl3 IL electrolytes. The EMI+ and HMI+ structures are included. (d) Relative MS intensity ratio between the ion pair ([EMI-Cl-EMI]+ or [HMI-Cl-HMI]+) and the respective isolated cation (EMI+ or HMI+) of the EMICl and HMICl salts from ESI-MS analysis. (e) Atomic ratio between Al (in anion), N (in cation) and O (from H2O) according to ARXPS results. (f) Schematic for the anion, cation and H2O distribution from the ARXPS measurements. Fig. 2 (a) 2D contour plots of the stage-n GIC (002), (00n + 1) and (00n + 2) reflection planes under charging conditions in operando XRD measurements with HMI-based electrolyte. (b) Representative operando XRD patterns with EMICl-AlCl3 (E) and HMICl-AlCl3 (H) electrolytes at different charging states. Fig. 3 Operando XPS analysis of the Al| HMICl-AlCl3| HOPG model battery. (a–c) A set of operando XPS Al 2p (a), N 1s (b) and C 1s (c) spectra of the model batteries when charging from OCV to 2.6 V. (d) Dependence of intercalated Cl (Clint, black circles and the black dashed line is the fitting result) and N (Nint) contents (red stars and the red dashed line is the fitting result) with intercalated Al (Alint) contents of the HMI-based electrolyte systems in the charging process. The corresponding results in EMI-based systems (black and red solid lines) are included [39]. (e) Atomic ratios between intercalated Al (Alint) and host-C (Chost) in HMI-based electrolyte systems at different potentials. The theory limit (black dashed line) for the Alint/Chost in EMICl-based systems at 2.45 V is also displayed [39]. Fig. 4 (a) Operando OM images captured over an exfoliated HOPG flake in HMICl-AlCl3 electrolyte at 2 V for the indicated charging times. Diffusion frontiers are highlighted by red dashed lines. (b) The intercalated area vs. time extracted from the operando OM images. The results in EMICl-AlCl3 electrolyte are included. (c) Correlation between the peak current (I p) and scan rate (v). (d) Nyquist plots of the model HOPG electrodes in EMICl-AlCl3 and HMICl-AlCl3 electrolytes acquired at 1.95 V upon the initial charging process. (e) GCD curves for the coin-type Al/graphite batteries after 20th cycles at 0.5 A g−1 (cutoff voltage: 2.42 V) using the two electrolytes. Scheme 1 Schematic illustration of the ion intercalation process without (a) and with (b) de-solvation. The schematic for the coordination structure of the solvated ion are deduced from the ARXPS measurements.The red balls, blue pentagons and the grean lines represent for the guest anions, imidazolium rings and the aliphatic side chains respectively. Graphical abstract The electrolyte coordination structure-dependent intercalation chemistry has been directly observed over an Al/graphite model battery using operando X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements which suggest a new method to investigate the electrolyte-dependent intercalation and interface chemistry. In-depth understanding of the electrolyte-dependent intercalation chemistry in batteries through direct operando/in situ characterizations is crucial for the development of the high-performance batteries. Herein, taking the Al/graphite battery as a model system, the effect of electrolyte coordination structure on the intercalation processes has been investigated over the batteries with either 1-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (HMICl)-AlCl3 or 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (EMICl)-AlCl3 ionic liquid electrolyte using operando X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-ray diffraction. With a weaker anion-cation interaction in HMI-based electrolyte, the XPS-derived atomic ratio between co-intercalated N and intercalated Al is 0.9, which is lower than 1.6 for EMI-based electrolyte. Attributed to the additional de-solvation process, the batteries with the HMI-based electrolyte show a lower ionic diffusion rate, capacity, and cycling performance, which agree with the operando characterization results. Our findings highlight the critical role of the electrolyte coordination structure on the (co–)intercalation chemistry. Keywords Operando surface characterization Electrolyte coordination structure De-solvation Intercalation chemistry 1 Introduction It is well known that the electrolyte lies at the heart of the battery and plays a critical role in the overall performance [1–6]. For instance, in the state-of-the-art lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), both the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) and intercalation chemistry are directly governed by electrolyte concentration [7–11], as well as its components including solvents [9,12–14], salts [9,15] and additives [16,17]. Typically, in the previously used propylene carbonate (PC)-based electrolytes, an unstable SEI composed of organic Li salts forms on the graphite anode. Such a poor SEI leads to Li+-solvent co-intercalation and exfoliation of the graphite anode [18]. In contrast, an effective SEI which forms in ethylene carbonate (EC)-based electrolyte with vinylene carbonate (VC) as the additive can inhibit the Li+-solvent co-intercalation and leads to reversible Li+ intercalation–deintercalation [19]. In addition to SEI, it is reported that the intercalation chemistry is also affected by the solvation or coordination structure of the intercalating ions [20–24]. For instance, Ming et al. discovered that the Li+-solvent co-intercalation into the graphite anode can still happen in dioxolane (DOL)/dimethoxymethane (DME) electrolyte after precoating the anode by the SEI formed in the commercial EC-based electrolyte which can inhibit the co-intercalation of the EC solvent. Furthermore, the Li+-solvent co-intercalation can be well inhibited by weakening the Li+-solvent interaction through introducing LiNO3 [20,21]. The critical role of the electrolyte coordination structure on the ionic intercalation processes can also be observed in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) [25–27], potassium-ion batteries [28–30], dual-ion batteries [31,32] and supercapacitors [33]. With respect to the poor Na+ storage performance of graphite electrode (< 35 mA h g−1) [34], many researches demonstrate that the limit can be bypassed via the solvent-assisted Na+ intercalation strategy using diglyme-based electrolytes [35,36]. For example, Pint’s group successfully designed an ultrafast Na/few-layer graphene cell with the diglyme-based electrolyte which can yield a capacity of > 150 mA h g−1 at 1 A g−1 and ∼ 100 mA h g−1 at 30 A g−1 over 8000 cycles [37]. Yoon et al. systematically studied Na+-solvent co-intercalation chemistry in various solvents by combining theoretical calculations with electrochemical performance tests. They found that both the Na+-solvent interaction and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital level of the [Na-solvent]+ complex control the reversible Na+ (de)intercalation [38]. In order to deeply understand the role of the electrolyte coordination structures in battery performance, it requires direct and operando characterization methodology. In this work, taking Al/graphite battery as a model system, we have studied the electrolyte coordination structure-dependent electrochemical intercalation behaviors by using operando X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). For the battery, either 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (EMICl)-AlCl3 or 1-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (HMICl)-AlCl3 ionic liquid (IL) is used as the electrolyte. In the IL electrolytes, the EMI+ or HMI+ cations act as the solvent of the guest chloroaluminate ( A l C l 4 - ) anions. As evaluated by XPS and mass spectrometry (MS), the coordination strength of HMI+ is lower than that of EMI+ and the corresponding anion-cation interaction is weaker in HMI-based electrolyte than that in EMI-based electrolyte. The intercalated N:Al atomic ratio is reduced from 1.6 in the EMI-based systems [39] to 0.9 in the HMI-based systems based on operando XPS measurements. Affected by the de-solvation processes, the batteries with HMI-based electrolyte demonstrate a much lower ionic diffusion rate, lower capacity, and poorer cycling performance, which are consistent with the higher stage graphite intercalation compound (GIC) with a lower intercalation concentration by operando XRD and XPS. Our results suggest that the de-solvation processes are mainly governed by the electrolyte coordination structure. Moreover, the methods demonstrated in this work can be applied to other systems, such as LIBs or SIBs, to study the electrolyte-dependent interface and intercalation chemistry. 2 Results and discussion Two kinds of IL electrolytes used in the Al/graphite batteries (Fig. 1 a) have been prepared by mixing EMICl ([C2C1Im]+Cl−) or HMICl ([C6C1Im]+Cl−) salt with anhydrous AlCl3 (AlCl3:EMICl or HMICl = 1.3:1, by mole). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of Al/highly orientated pyrolyzed graphite (HOPG) batteries with the two electrolytes are respectively shown in Fig. 1(b) between 1.50–2.45 V (vs. Al quasi-reference electrode) under 0.5 mV s−1. Typically, the sharp oxidative peaks around 1.85, 2.10 and 2.40 V can be clearly seen in the EMI-based system upon charging (positive polarization), which correspond to the anion intercalation processes [39–41]. In contrast, the CV curve with tiny broad peaks and a lower current density is acquired in the HMI-based systems. Furthermore, the intercalation potential in HMI-based electrolyte can be determined as 1.90 V which is larger than 1.82 V in EMI-based electrolyte (inset of Fig. 1b). The above results demonstrate that the cation structure of IL electrolyte strongly affects the electrochemical behaviors. To figure out the underlying mechanism of the distinct electrochemical behaviors, a comparison of the anion-cation interaction in the two ILs has been performed by XPS. As shown in Fig. 1(c), the binding energy of the imidazole N atom Ncation 1s in EMI-based electrolyte is located at 402.7 eV (other elements are shown in Fig. S1). In comparison, the Ncation 1s signal from the HMI-based electrolyte displays a broadened feature and has a shoulder band at 403.6 eV, showing that the charge of Ncation as well as the imidazolium ring in HMI-based electrolyte is more positive than that in EMI-based electrolyte. Such results suggest that the less electron is transferred from the anion to cation which causes the less charge delocalization of the imidazolium ring in HMI-based electrolyte. Thus, it can be concluded that the anion-cation interaction is weaker in HMI-based electrolyte (Fig. 1f) [42–44]. Such conclusions can be further supported by the 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and infrared (IR) spectra of the electrolytes shown in Figs. S2 and S3, respectively. The higher chemical shifts of H atoms and lower wavenumbers of the corresponding CH x modes in HMI-based electrolyte demonstrate that the positive charge density of the imidazolium ring is higher as well as the anion-cation interaction is weaker. The coordination strength of these two cations has been also evaluated by electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) [45,46]. As shown in Fig. 1(d) and Fig. S4, the MS intensity ratio between the ion pair ([EMI-Cl-EMI]+) and the isolated cation (EMI+) in EMI-based IL electrolyte can reach 46%, which is much higher than 2% ([HMI-Cl-HMI]+/HMI+) in HMI-based IL electrolyte. The ESI-MS results further support the XPS results, indicating that the anion-cation interaction is weaker in HMI-based electrolyte. Angle-resolved XPS (ARXPS) measurements were carried out over the IL surface in ultra-high vacuum (UHV) to investigate the depth-dependent chemical information and coordination structure (Fig. S1). As shown in Fig. 1(e), the surface enrichment of the cation [44,47] can be observed in HMI-based electrolyte compared with EMI-based one according to the higher N/Al ratio. Moreover, the distribution of contaminated H2O molecules (from O 1s [48]), which is mainly produced by the reactions between acid IL electrolyte and aluminum oxide films on Al anode (determined by Karl Fischer titrator shown in Fig. S5), has been measured by ARXPS (O/Al in Fig. 1e). H2O is mainly distributed in the topmost surface region of EMI-based electrolyte but in the bulk region of HMI-based electrolyte. We suggest that the weak anion-cation interaction in HMI-based electrolyte allows H2O molecules to enter the bulk anion-cation networks (Fig. 1f), which may further influence the corresponding electrochemical behaviors [48]. Electrochemical intercalation processes upon charging under LSV condition (1.8–2.65 V, 0.1 mV s−1) and the following constant voltage charging at 2.65 V in HMICl-AlCl3 electrolyte have been investigated by operando XRD over the model Al/HOPG battery. Fig. 2 (a) shows two-dimensional (2D) contour patterns of reflections from the (002) plane (middle panel) of the pristine uncharged graphite, as well as the (00n + 1) (left panel) and (00n + 2) (right panel) planes of the generated stage-n GIC electrodes in HMI-based system. Under a linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) condition from 1.80 to 2.65 V with 0.1 mV s−1 and the subsquent constant-voltage charge at 2.65 V for 2400 s (right panel in Fig. 2a), intensity of the pristine uncharged (002) pattern gradually decreases along with the increasing (00n + 1) and (00n + 2) signals. At 2.15 V, the (00n + 1) and (00n + 2) diffraction patterns appear at 23.9° and 27.9° which are corresponding to the (006) and (007) planes of a stage-5 GIC structure, respectively. When the potential reaches to 2.25 V, a stage-4 GIC can be observed, for which (005) and (006) diffraction peaks are located at 23.5° and 28.2° and become profound during the subsequent charging process to 2.65 V. After charging at 2.65 V for 1800 s (Fig. 2a), two dominant (005) and (006) diffraction patterns are observed which demonstrates the formation of a pure stage-4 GIC [49,50]. Operando XRD characterization results over the HOPG model electrode in EMI-based electrolyte under the same charging condition (LSV: 1.80–2.45 V, 0.1 mV s−1) are shown in Fig. S6. Similiarly, the intensity of the pristine (002) peak gradually decreases and the (00n + 1) and (00n + 2) peaks appear upon charging and shift to 22.5° and 28.2° after charging to 2.45 V, respectively [39,48]. Some typical operando XRD patterns recorded over HOPG electrodes in HMI- (labelled as H) and EMI- (labelled as E) based systems are comparativley displayed in Fig. 2(b). At open circuit voltage (OCV) state, the (002) XRD pattterns are located at 26.5° indicating the same pristine structure with an interlayer spacing of 3.35 Å. Under the same charging condition (LSV: 1.80–2.45 V, 0.1 mV s−1), a pure stage-3 GIC structure whose gallery height is 9.1 Å can be observed at 2.45 V in EMI-based system as seen from the well-defined (004) and (005) diffraction peaks located at 22.5° and 28.2°, respectively. In comparision, a pure stage-4 GIC structure with the calculated gallery height of 8.9 Å [50,51] can be formed at 2.65 V (albeit with a longer charging period of 2400 s shown in Fig. 2(b) in HMICl-AlCl3 electrolyte. The operando XRD results confirm the coordination structure-dependent intercalation processes in the two electrolytes, and show that the GIC structure with a higher stage can be acquired at higher charging potential in HMI-based electrolyte than that in EMI-based electrolyte. The coordination structure effect on intercalation chemistry in the two electrolytes can be further investigated by operando XPS. By constructing well-defined planar Al/HOPG model batteries (Fig. S7) and using UHV-compatible IL electrolytes, operando XPS measurements have been successfully carried out over the EMI-based system [39,48]. The intercalation of A l C l 4 - together with EMI+ has been directly observed. Electrochemical intercalation mechanism in the HMI-based system has been further studied by operando XPS measurements over the planar Al|HMICl-AlCl3|HOPG model batteries in this work (detail in experimental section). A set of operando XPS Al 2p, N 1s and C 1s signals acquired at different charging potentials are shown in Fig. 3 (a–c) and Fig. S8, respectively. At the OCV state, Al 2p spectrum is peaked at 75.9 eV (Fig. 3a) which can be assigned to A l x C l y - in the IL electrolyte (Alads) adsorbing on the HOPG electrode surface and is similar to the pure IL droplet (Fig. S9a). When the charging potential reaches to 1.95 V, a new Al 2p signal (red part in Fig. 3a) at 74.2 eV can be observed, whose BE is 1.7 eV lower than that at the OCV state. We assign the signals to the intercalated Al (Alint), and the negative BE shift (−1.7 eV) with respect to Alads is corresponding to the Fermi level shift, i.e., increment of the surface work function by 1.7 eV (Fig. S10) [39,52,53]. The peaks at higher BEs (blue part) are attributed to the hydrous species due to the entry of H2O into the bulk anion-cation networks as discussed in Fig. 1(f) [48]. During charging to 2.6 V, the Alint 2p signal intensity continues to increase. The evolution of N 1s signal (Fig. 3b) is similar to Al 2p. Upon charging, N 1s signal located at 400.3 eV appears and increases gradually from OCV to 2.6 V, whose BE is 1.7 eV lower than that in OCV state. The depth-profile XPS measurement assisted with Ar+ sputtering has been performed and shown in Fig. S11. Upon Ar+ etching, the Al 2p and N 1s BEs from the bulk region are consistent with those from the surface region acquired by the operando XPS measurements. Such results demonstrate that this newly appeared N 1s signal is assigned to the co-intercalated HMI+ cations within the HOPG electrode instead of surface adsorption on the electrode. Thus, the anion-cation co-intercalation is also involved in the Al|HMICl-AlCl3|HOPG battery. Furthermore, the depth-profile XPS and the chemical analysis results (Fig. S12) confirm that the concentrations of intercalated anions and cations are lower in the bulk region compared with the surface region. The selected operando XPS C 1s signals at OCV and 2.6 V are shown in Fig. 3(c). C 1s intensity decreases strongly after charging due to attenuation of the intercalated ions. In addition to some complex functional groups (dash line in Fig. 3c), the C 1s band at OCV mainly consists of the adsorbed IL species, including adsorbed C-N ((C–N)ads, green part) at 286.8 eV and adsorbed C–C ((C–C)ads, patterned green part) at 285.3 eV (the same as the IL droplet, Fig. S9b), and the uncharged carbon atoms (Cuc) at 284.5 eV. The co-intercalation of HMI+ can be further proved by the fact that the intercalated C–N ((C–N)int) and C–C ((C–C)int) signals can be found at 285.1 and 283.6 eV at 2.6 V, respectively, whose BEs are also 1.7 eV lower than the (C–N)ads and (C–C)ads. In addition, the charged carbon atoms (Cc, pink part in Fig. 3c) shift negatively to 283.1 eV, which is 1.4 eV lower than Cuc (Fig. S10). The quantitative information of the intercalated species and GICs can be further derived from the operando XPS analysis. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the atomic ratio of the intercalated Nint/Alint is calculated as 0.9 in HMI-based systems, which is lower than 1.6 in the EMI-based systems (red solid line) [39]. Thus, the operando XPS analysis directly demonstrates the stronger de-solvation processes in HMI-based systems, which is due to the weaker anion-cation interaction. In addition, Clint/Alint in HMI-based electrolyte is 3.2 and lower than that in EMI-based one (Clint/Alint = 4.1:1 (black solid line in Fig. 3d) [39], which may be due to the hydrolysis from replacement of Cl by OH [48]. Fig. 3(e) displays the atomic ratios between intercalated Al (Alint) and host-C (Chost) in HMI-based systems at different potentials. At 2.6 V, the ratio of Alint/Chost can reach 1:5, which is much lower than 1:1.7 in EMICl-based systems at 2.45 V (red star in Fig. 3e), but still ∼5-fold higher than the theoretical limit, i.e., Alint/Chost = 1: 24 (dashed line in Fig. 3e) [49]. Combined with the operando XRD measurements (Fig. 2), it can be concluded that the GIC formed in HMI-based systems has a higher stage structure, that is, with a lower (co–)intercalation concentration, compared with EMI-based systems. The different electrochemical behaviors observed in the above characterizations may strongly affect the performance. The ion transport processes within the graphite electrode have been recorded by operando optical microscope (OM) measurements. A set of OM images of a single exfoliated HOPG flake are captured upon charging at 2 V as shown in Fig. 4 (a) and Video S1, in which the intercalated regions can be distinguished by the dark contrast. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the intercalated area increases approximately linearly with time [54] since that the OM images were captured under the current-steady conditions. Derived from the slope of the linear fit of the intercalated area vs. time curves, the transport rate of the intercalated ions can be estimated as 5.4 × 10−6 cm2 s−1 (black line in Fig. 4b) in HMICl-AlCl3 electrolyte, which is one order lower than 3.9 × 10−5 cm2 s−1 in EMICl-AlCl3 electrolyte (red line in Fig. 4b, Fig. S13 and Video S2). Furthermore, the appearance diffusion coefficients (D) in the two electrolytes are measured by CV tests over the Al/HOPG model batteries (Fig. S14) under various scan rates (v). According to the Randles-Sevcik equation, peak current (I p) and scan rate (v) follow the formula: I p = 269000 n 3 / 2 A C D 1 / 2 v 1 / 2 (A: the working electrode area; C: concentration; D: diffusion coefficient) [41,55]. Thus, D in the two electrolytes can be obtained based on the dependence of I p on v 1/2. As shown in Fig. 4(c), D in HMI-based system is only 1/16 of that in EMI-based system. To clarify the main factor of the different ion transport kinetics in the above two electrolytes, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis has been further conducted. To begin with, the ionic conductivity of these two electrolytes were measured by EIS measurements using Ta as the blocking electrode which are shown in Fig. S15. The ionic conductivity of HMI-based electrolyte is 7.4 mS cm−1, which is only slightly lower than 16.7 mS cm−1 in EMI-based electrolyte. According to the Nernst-Einstein equation: σ = n e 2 kT D e , the diffusion coefficients of the ion in the electrolyte (D e) is in direct proportional to the ionic conductivity ( σ ) of the electrolyte [56]. Thus, the liquid-phase ionic diffusion coefficient in the EMI-based electrolyte is only about 2-fold higher than that in the HMI-based electrolyte. The EIS measurements have been further performed over the Al/HOPG model batteries. Fig. 4(d) shows the Nyquist plots in the above two electrolytes acquired at 1.95 V. Both Nyquist plots showed a single semicircle at the high-frequency range and a straight line rising at the low-frequency region, which are attributed to the charge-transfer resistance and the diffusion resistance, respectively. Based on the equivalent circuit shown in Fig. S16, the charge-transfer resistance in HMI-based electrolyte can be estimated as 56 Ω, which is approximately 5-fold higher than 12 Ω in the EMI-based electrolyte. Otherwise, the diffusion coefficient in the bulk region can be yielded as 9.59 × 10−13 cm2 s−1 in the EMI-based electrolyte, which is slightly higher than 7.2 × 10−13 cm2 s−1 in the HMI-based electrolyte (the detailed derivation processes are described in SI). Overall, the observed large difference in ionic intercalation kinetics between HMI- and EMI-based systems should not be from the small difference in the liquid- and solid- phase ionic diffusion coefficients but from the interfacial charge transfer resistance, i.e., the occurrence of the de-solvation processes. The operando XPS measurements show that there exists the considerable discrepancy on the concentration of the intercalated anions and cations of these two electrolytes which may strongly affect the total charge density (TCD) of the electrode (TCD= −Alint/Chost + 1/2·Nint/Chost) as well as the battery capacity. Cycling performance tests of the coin-type Al/graphite batteries have been further carried out over the nano-thick graphite electrode. The galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves after the 20th cycle at 0.5 A g−1 with a cutoff voltage of 2.42 V using the two electrolytes are shown in Fig. 4(e). The capacity in HMI-based system is ∼51 mA h g−1, in contrast with ∼109 mA h g−1 in EMI-based system, which is highly consistent with the XPS-derived TCD values (−0.11 and −0.06 per C atom for EMI- and HMI-based electrolyte respectively) at 2.4 V. This suggests that while the EMI-based electrolyte has more co-intercalation, the corresponding capacity is even higher due to the much higher concentration of the intercalated guest anions. This may be interpreted as a decrease in Coulomb repulsion between the intercalated anions assisted by the co-intercalation cations. The discharge plateau with HMICl-AlCl3 electrolyte is 1.82 V which is much lower than 2.25 V with EMICl-AlCl3 electrolyte. The contribution of the electric double layer capacitance (EDLC) has been further measured [57,58]. The EDLC of the EMI- and HMI-based electrolytes can be calculated as 22 and 13 μF cm−2 respectively based on the CV tests (Fig. S17), which can contribute capacity of 0.29 and 0.11 mA h g−1 (Fig. S18). The negligible contribution of the EDLC indicates that the differenrce of the cycling performance is owing to the distinct intercalation chemistry observed by our above operando characterization methods showing a higher intercalation stage-structure and a lower intercalation concentration in HMI-based system. The long-term cyclic performance at 0.5 A g−1 is shown in Fig. S19. Compared with the stable capacity at 110 mA h g−1 and with 95% efficiency using EMICl-AlCl3 electrolyte, the capacity of the HMI-based system increases slightly upon cycling along with the decreasing efficiency, which may be due to the side reactions caused by the internal H2O. More obvious irreversible intercalation–deintercalation can be found when the cutoff voltage is set above 2.6 V but no remarkable electrolyte decomposition occurs (Figs. S20 and S21). The online gas analysis (Fig. S22) shows that O2 appears continually upon charging in HMI-based system while almost no gaseous products can be detected in EMI-based system. Such results indicate that the residual water in the electrolytes plays a negative role since it can trigger the side reactions and lower the Coulombic efficiency [40,48]. Overall, the batteries with HMI-based electrolyte perform larger inercalation overpotential, lower ionic diffusion rate, smaller capacity, and poorer cycling performance. Based on the above results, the coordination structure effect on the intercalation chemistry can be illustrated by Scheme 1 . With a weaker anion-cation interaction, the de-solvent processes are more likely to happen in HMI-based electrolyte than EMI-based electrolyte. Such conclusions can be directly validated by using operando XPS measurements showing that the atomic ratio of the intercalated Nint/Alint is 0.9 in HMI-based electrolyte, which is lower than 1.6 in EMI-based electrolyte [39]. The additional de-solvation processes in HMI-based systems should pose an extra de-solvation energy [59–61] (Scheme 1b) during the ion transfer across the electrolyte-graphite interface and lead to a large intercalation overpotential and the sluggish diffusion process whose ionic diffusion rate is one order less than that of EMI-based systems (Scheme 1a) as revealed by operando OM measurements and CV tests. Combined with the operando XPS and EIS measuremnts, it can be unambiguously proved that the de-solvation processes is a rate-determining step of the battery and the use of the electrolyte with low coordination strength can significantly reduce the de-solvation energy [62]. In addition to the diffusion kinetics, the de-solvation in HMI-based systems also leads to the strong coulomb repulsion between the intercalated anions within graphite and thus the low capacity (∼50 mA h g−1, half of that in EMI-based electrolyte ∼ 110 mA h g−1). Furthermore, the internal H2O impurities in HMI-based electrolyte also cause the lower efficiency and poorer cycling performance. 3 Conclusions In summary, the effect of the electrolyte coordination structure on the intercalation chemistry has been extensively investigated based on the operando characterizations over model Al/HOPG batteries with EMI- or HMI-based IL electrolytes in this work. Due to the weak anion-cation interaction, the de-solvation processes in the HMI-based systems have been observed by the operando XPS measurements. Such de-solvation process further causes the sluggish intercalation kinetics and a lower capacity of the batteries. This work provides direct evidence that de-solvation is a rate-determining step in the batteries. Such methods can be extended to other energy storage systems exploring the solvation effect on the intercalation and interface chemistry in batteries. coredata.dc:description: In-depth understanding of the electrolyte-dependent intercalation chemistry in batteries through direct operando/in situ characterizations is crucial for the development of the high-performance batteries. Herein, taking the Al/graphite battery as a model system, the effect of electrolyte coordination structure on the intercalation processes has been investigated over the batteries with either 1-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (HMICl)-AlCl3 or 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (EMICl)-AlCl3 ionic liquid electrolyte using operando X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-ray diffraction. With a weaker anion-cation interaction in HMI-based electrolyte, the XPS-derived atomic ratio between co-intercalated N and intercalated Al is 0.9, which is lower than 1.6 for EMI-based electrolyte. Attributed to the additional de-solvation process, the batteries with the HMI-based electrolyte show a lower ionic diffusion rate, capacity, and cycling performance, which agree with the operando characterization results. Our findings highlight the critical role of the electrolyte coordination structure on the (co–)intercalation chemistry.
